comments:
This course introduces students to drug discovery and development through an overview of biochemistry and the drug market. Topics include enzyme kinetics, cell-based screening, high-throughput screening, ADMET, FDA approval processes, and drug delivery.

Students found the course “interesting” but the exams “reflect more on general chemistry [from freshman year of undergraduate study] and less on the course at hand.” Many students indicated the lack of mathematical examples and the need for textbook and/or other supplementary materials and references for the class. Students also reported that the student presentations were “uninteresting” and unnecessary.

Students commented that Professor Diamond was “enthusiastic” but “talks extremely fast” that could result in missing critical information. Students gave mixed reviews about Professor Diamond’s teaching style. A student praised his lectures as “concise” and “logical” while another said they were “hard to follow” and “not very helpful.” 

Although it is a graduate class, undergraduate CBE majors may take it for concentration in pharmaceutics and biotechnology.
